text.p: These are the leading stories in the Belgrade press on Monday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Turnout at Yugoslavia's federal elections was 61%. The left coalition SPS-JUL-DS is overwhelmingly in the lead according to latest unofficial results.
- Montenegro's ruling Democratic Party of Socialists proclaims its victory at the republican elections which were held together with the federal and local elections.
- The country's foreign trade deficit should be reduced to $700 million from $1.2 billion by the end of the year says chairman of the assembly of the Serbian chamber of commerce Rajko Uncanin.
- U.S. human rights envoy John Shattuck says fulfilment of Dayton agreement is in the interest of all parties during his visit to Bosnian Serb town of Banja Luka.
- Yugoslavia's foreign debt is not a good investment according to a report of an influential investment bank in London.

- Serbian electricity company (EPS) is completing negotiations wiht the help of Beobanka Ad for a Czech loan of $100 million to continue construction of thermal power plant Kolubara B. It has almost secured an additional $60 million from other foreign partners.

- Vranje furniture factory Simpo registers good sales on domestic market and expects to earn $40 million from exports by the end of the year which is 20 percent higher than the previous year. -- Belgrade newsroom +381 11 2224305
